content.title: Energy Efficiency (SDG 7.3)
content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 3

content.text: Framed within SDG 7.3, the global energy efficiency target requires significant reductions in energy consumption, presenting both synergies and trade-offs on global and local scales. Energy efficiency presents synergistic opportunities of reducing planetary impacts and promoting sustainable societies. Yet, adopting these measures faces challenges, such as navigating the complexities of industrial degrowth and balancing economic and social impacts.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: energy and digitalization
concepts.body: Energy and digitalization refers to the integration of digital technologies into the energy sector, enhancing efficiency, management, and innovation in energy production, distribution, and consumption.

concepts.title: energy efficiency
concepts.body: Energy efficiency refers to using less energy to perform the same task or produce the same outcome, thereby reducing energy waste and lowering costs.

concepts.title: waste-to-energy solutions
concepts.body: Waste-to-energy solutions are processes that convert non-recyclable waste materials into usable forms of energy, typically electricity or heat, through methods such as combustion, gasification, or anaerobic digestion.

content.text: By 2030, double the global rate of improvement in energy efficiency. Indicators 7.3.1 Energy intensity measured in terms of primary energy and GDP

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 3 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Catalyzing Sustainability through Energy Efficiency

content.text: Improving energy efficiency can provide over 40% of the emissions reductions needed to meet global climate targets without relying on new technologies. Investments in energy efficiency can serve as a catalyst for broader sustainable development, offering cost-effective solutions that address multiple challenges simultaneously. Examples include reducing greenhouse gas emissions (SDG 13) and lowering energy costs for businesses and households (SDG 8), simultaneously addressing environmental and economic challenges while creating a ripple effect of positive impacts across various sectors.

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 3 | Part 1 | A
content.title: A. Building Sustainable Societies through Energy Efficiency

content.text: Energy efficiency is key to reducing several adverse effects of the two previous SDG 7.1 and SDG 7.2. On the one hand, energy efficiency measures can reduce the rebound effect of energy access. For instance, an integrated solution developed by the ICLEI organization enhanced to improve water and energy efficiency of health centers and maternity centers, addressing together several SDG such as 3, 5, 6 and 7 (Box 14), enhancing a more positive impact of energy access interventions. On the other hand, since energy efficiency reduces the amount of energy consumption, it has direct impacts on reducing energy-related environmental effects on climate (SDG 13). The UAE Consensus reaffirms the global commitment to doubling the rate of energy efficiency improvements by 2030, recognizing it as a critical pillar for sustainable energy transitions and emissions reductions.

The Green Economic Development Project developed by the UNDP in Bosnia Herzegovina led to saving 700,000 USD annually, reducing emissions by 2.2 tons of CO2 annually and creating jobs for 664 people / month (SDG 8) (Box 15), contributing to sustainable cities, climate, education and energy goals. Nature-based solutions are gaining traction, counteracting heat waves and high temperatures in urban settings. By incorporating elements like blue infrastructure and green roofs, these approaches reduce per capita energy consumption and enhance urban microclimates (SDG 11) (WB, 2023).

The Green Economic Development Project developed by the UNDP from 2012 to 2022 has improved the energy efficiency of public buildings in Bosnia and Herzegovina for climate comfort. It has promoted fuel switch projects, automated energy consumption regulation and management of public-sector buildings, and implemented efficient public lighting. Education and capacity-building on energy management of public-sector buildings for end-users have also been provided (source: UNDP BiH).

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 3 | Part 1 | B
content.title: B. Optimizing the Water-Food-Energy Nexus for Sustainability

content.text: The growing demand for water (SDG 6), food (SDG 2), and energy (SDG 7) exerts immense pressure on this interconnected nexus. For instance, shifting dietary patterns towards water-intensive foods, coupled with an anticipated population surge to over 9 billion by 2050, could necessitate a staggering 50% increase in global food production. Integrated and efficient management of water, food, and energy presents synergistic opportunities to address these multiple challenges. Optimizing power plant operations, deploying advanced cooling systems, and embracing energy-efficient irrigation present viable solutions. Water services, acting as a cornerstone for demand-side energy management, offer opportunities for power generation and storage, with irrigation adjustments during low electricity demand periods and reduced pumping during peaks (IEA, 2023). The intertwined nature of land, soil, and water systems calls for comprehensive efficiency measures across the agri-food chain. Precision irrigation guided by water providers' data and the safeguarding of ecosystems alongside agricultural and energy production are novel solutions to ensure environmental sustainability (UN Water, 2023). Efficient cold chain solutions are also key for supporting food security while reducing food waste (FAO, 2021).

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 3 | Part 1 | C
content.title: C. Waste-to-energy Solutions

content.text: The UNDP's project in Sri Lanka, spanning 2019 to 2023, targets sustainable energy use in the Agro-Industry to cut emissions and boost savings. Focused on solar energy and biogas, the project exemplifies a South-South cooperation led by China. It aims to build capacity, transfer technology, and apply biogas solutions, including converting slurry into organic fertilizer. By showcasing energy-efficient applications, waste management, and productivity gains, the project benefits from China's expertise, fostering capacity development in partner countries (source: UNDP).

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 3 | Part 1 | D
content.title: D. Digitalization for Efficiency

content.text: Integrating digital solutions with energy infrastructure creates synergies, enabling increased efficiency and productivity (SDG 9, 11, 12). Fourth Industrial Revolution technologies, like real-time analytics, significantly enhance energy efficiency and reduce waste across various channels (UNDP, 2018). Developing nations have immense potential to adopt Industry 4.0 in manufacturing, employing smart production tools like real-time analytics, automation, the Internet of Things (IoT) and Artificial Intelligences (AI) to enhance productivity and minimize environmental impact (UN, 2022). Agriculture 4.0, which leverages precision farming, autonomous machinery, AI-driven monitoring, and IoT-enabled smart irrigation, is also emerging for enhanced farming practices. Agricultural automation trends include creating specialized equipment for farming tasks and converting standard machinery into autonomous systems (FAO, 2020). Smart cities and grids, driven by digital tech, optimize urban infrastructure and energy networks. UNDP-supported projects in places like Mauritius to introduce smart grid solutions that automate responses to outages and improve reliability and power quality. In Bosnia and Herzegovina, digital tech monitors and reduces building power consumption, critical for emissions reduction. Tracking energy use and emissions in 75% of buildings aids in efficient planning and disaster mitigation ( Box 15) (UNDP, 2023). More on energy efficiency in buildings, industries and cooling in Module 6.

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 3 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Developing Informed Strategies for Energy Efficiency Trade-offs

content.text: Developing informed strategies for energy efficiency trade-offs involves balancing competing priorities when implementing energy-saving measures. Key aspects include weighing upfront costs against long-term savings and considering potential conflicts between efficiency upgrades and historical preservation in buildings.

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 3 | Part 2 | A
content.title: A. Scaling Nature-Based Solutions for Addressing Inequalities and Land Challenges

content.text: Nature-based solutions (NBS) stand as a promising avenue for scaling up energy efficiency by leveraging ecosystems to regulate temperatures, enhance insulation, and reduce energy demand in buildings and infrastructure. For instance, urban green infrastructure, such as green roofs and tree-lined streets, lowers cooling costs by mitigating the urban heat island effect, while wetland restoration can enhance water retention and reduce the energy needed for water treatment and distribution. In agriculture, agroforestry and regenerative farming improve soil moisture retention, reducing irrigation-related energy consumption. However, the substantial land requirements of large-scale nature-based solutions, especially for climate change mitigation (i.e. carbon capture solutions), require simultaneous actions to ease land pressure, such as shifts in food systems and agriculture, to prevent potential conflicts. Inclusive design becomes critical considering the historical impact on marginalized communities amid land and climate changes. Challenges to wider adoption include limitations in ecosystem services, monitoring difficulties, and varying societal perceptions of climate risks (WWF, 2020). Mitigating potential trade-offs and avoiding exacerbating climate issues and social injustices require integrated, bottom-up approaches. UNDP's initiatives, particularly in tackling deforestation through nature-based solutions, exemplify this comprehensive strategy (Box 17).

In Angola, where 88% of the multidimensionally poor reside in rural areas facing threats from deforestation and traditional energy usage, the UNDP collaborates with the government to address this critical issue. Angola's 2020-2022 development priority emphasizes natural resource management for conservation and economic growth. UNDP's approach involves integrated, nature-based solutions targeting deforestation and forest degradation. Efforts concentrate on sustainable forest management, notably community-based forestry, and enhancing the sustainability of the charcoal value chain. This includes promoting sustainable charcoal consumption practices in cities and integrating sustainability criteria into government policies, fostering long-term environmental preservation and benefiting rural communities (source: SDG).

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 2 | Lesson 3 | Part 2 | B
content.title: B. Sustainability Education and Behavioral Approaches for Shaping a Greener Future

content.text: Effective achievement of energy efficiency goals demands broad cooperation (SDG 17) and requires education on sustainability (SDG 12). Creating widespread awareness and understanding among governments, industries, and communities is paramount for an initiative’s success (WEF, 2023). While technology is essential, influencing consumer behavior significantly impacts energy savings. For instance, smart metering and real-time feedback systems have been shown to reduce household energy consumption by 5-15%. Behavioral approaches can reshape energy efficiency programs by integrating social norms, incentives, and nudging techniques. An example is the "Cool Biz" campaign in Japan, which encourages businesses to relax dress codes and reduce air conditioning use, has saved an estimated 1.4 million tons of CO₂ emissions annually. In India, the Unnat Jyoti by Affordable LEDs for All (UJALA) program leveraged bulk procurement and behavioral campaigns to distribute over 360 million LED bulbs, reducing annual electricity consumption by 47 billion kWh. Successful energy efficiency initiatives require a mix of technology-driven solutions and a deep, contextual understanding of human behavior. This emphasizes tailored, cost-effective approaches, continual evaluation, and engagement with communication experts in crafting effective behavior change campaigns. Behavioral approaches can reshape energy efficiency programs, focusing on behavior change and gender equality. These programs need to consider local contexts and consumer data, possibly integrating them into broader interventions (UNDP, 2024; ESMAP, 2020).

Education on energy efficiency encourages the development of technologies that minimize energy wastage and promotes collaborative research into renewable and clean energy resources (UNESCO, 2023). UNICEF’s Climate Change Strategy highlights the role of education in raising awareness and fostering youth-led climate action. For instance, UNICEF's "Green Skills for Youth" initiative trains young people in sustainable practices, equipping them with the knowledge and skills to implement energy efficiency measures in schools and communities. Overcoming challenges involves inclusive capacity-building efforts across sectors, focusing on individuals regardless of age or gender, particularly targeting women and youth (SDG 5) (FAO, 2020). Beyond education and behavior change, financing mechanisms play a crucial role in scaling energy efficiency. Governments and financial institutions have introduced innovative financing models such as green loans, energy service companies (ESCOs), and on-bill financing to encourage businesses and households to invest in energy-efficient solutions. More on energy financing in Module 4.

content.title: Key Takeaways
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Improving energy efficiency can provide over 40% of the emissions reductions needed to meet global climate targets without relying on new technologies.

Energy efficiency represents a highly advantageous strategy capable of catalyzing sustainability by building sustainable societies, optimizing the water-food-energy nexus, transforming the energy sector and industry through waste-to-energy solutions and digitalization.

Achieving energy efficiency requires not only technological advancements but also a change in societal behaviors, driven by sustainability education, inclusive capacity-building, and community engagement.
